section.name: Overview
section.p: Each of these naming modules validates identifiers for particular code elements. Valid identifiers for a naming module are specified by its format property. The value of format is a pattern for valid identifiers.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Validates abbreviations (consecutive capital letters) length in identifier name, it also allows to enforce camel case naming. Please read more at
Google Style Guide to get to know how to avoid long abbreviations in names.

allowedAbbreviationLength specifies how many consecutive capital letters are allowed in the identifier. A value of 3 indicates that up to 4 consecutive capital letters are allowed, one after the other, before a violation is printed. The identifier 'MyTEST' would be allowed, but 'MyTESTS' would not be. A value of 0 indicates that only 1 consecutive capital letter is allowed. This is what should be used to enforce strict camel casing. The identifier 'MyTest' would be allowed, but 'MyTEst' would not be.

ignoreFinal, ignoreStatic, and ignoreStaticFinal control whether variables with the respective modifiers are to be ignored. Note that a variable that is both static and final will always be considered under ignoreStaticFinal only, regardless of the values of ignoreFinal and ignoreStatic. So for example if ignoreStatic is true but ignoreStaticFinal is false, then static final variables will not be ignored.

tr.td: Indicate the number of consecutive capital letters allowed in targeted identifiers (abbreviations in the classes, interfaces, variables and methods names, ... ).
Specify abbreviations that must be skipped for checking.
Allow to skip variables with final modifier.
Allow to skip variables with static modifier.
Allow to skip variables with both static and final modifiers.
Allow to ignore methods tagged with @Override annotation (that usually mean inherited name).

subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , PARAMETER_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , METHOD_DEF , ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF , PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF , RECORD_DEF , RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF .
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , PARAMETER_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , METHOD_DEF , PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF , RECORD_DEF , RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"/>
subsection.p: To configure to include static variables and methods tagged with @Override annotation.
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="false"/> <property name="ignoreOverriddenMethods" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure to check all variables and identifiers (including ones with the static modifier) and enforce no abbreviations (essentially camel case) except for words like 'XML' and 'URL'.
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF,CLASS_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="false"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="0"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviations" value="XML,URL,O"/> </module>

public class MyClass { // OK int firstNum; // OK int secondNUM; // violation, it allowed only 1 consecutive capital letter static int thirdNum; // OK, the static modifier would be checked static int fourthNUm; // violation, the static modifier would be checked, // and only 1 consecutive capital letter is allowed String firstXML; // OK, XML abbreviation is allowed String firstURL; // OK, URL abbreviation is allowed final int TOTAL = 5; // OK, final is ignored static final int LIMIT = 10; // OK, static final is ignored void newOAuth2Client() {} // OK, O abbreviation is allowed void OAuth2() {} // OK, O abbreviation is allowed void OAUth2() {} // violation, OA abbreviation is not allowed // split occurs as 'OA', 'Uth2' }
subsection.p: To configure to check variables, excluding fields with the static modifier, and allow abbreviations up to 2 consecutive capital letters ignoring the longer word 'CSV'.
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="true"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="1"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviations" value="CSV"/> </module>

public class MyClass { // OK, ignore checking the class name int firstNum; // OK, abbreviation "N" is of allowed length 1 int secondNUm; // OK int secondMYNum; // violation, found "MYN" but only // 2 consecutive capital letters are allowed int thirdNUM; // violation, found "NUM" but it is allowed // only 2 consecutive capital letters static int fourthNUM; // OK, variables with static modifier // would be ignored String firstCSV; // OK, CSV abbreviation is allowed String firstXML; // violation, XML abbreviation is not allowed final int TOTAL = 5; // OK, final is ignored static final int LIMIT = 10; // OK, static final is ignored }
subsection.p: To configure to check variables, enforcing no abbreviations except for variables that are both static and final.
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreFinal" value="false"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="false"/> <property name="ignoreStaticFinal" value="true"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="0"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure to check variables, enforcing no abbreviations and ignoring static (but non-final) variables only.
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreFinal" value="false"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="true"/> <property name="ignoreStaticFinal" value="false"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="0"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Ensures that the names of abstract classes conforming to some pattern and check that abstract modifier exists.

Rationale: Abstract classes are convenience base class implementations of interfaces, not types as such. As such they should be named to indicate this. Also, if names of classes starts with 'Abstract' it's very convenient that they will have abstract modifier.

tr.td: Control whether to ignore checking for the abstract modifier on classes that match the name.
Control whether to ignore checking the name. Realistically only useful if using the check to identify that match name and do not have the abstract modifier.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="AbstractClassName"/>

abstract class AbstractFirstClass {} // OK abstract class SecondClass {} // violation, it should match pattern "^Abstract.+$" class AbstractThirdClass {} // violation, must be declared 'abstract' class FourthClass {} // OK
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it check name but ignore abstract modifier:
subsection.source: <module name="AbstractClassName"> <property name="ignoreModifier" value="true"/> </module>

abstract class AbstractFirstClass {} // OK abstract class SecondClass {} // violation, it should match pattern "^Abstract.+$" class AbstractThirdClass {} // OK, no "abstract" modifier class FourthClass {} // OK
subsection.p: To configure the check to ignore name validation when class declared as 'abstract'
subsection.source: <module name="AbstractClassName"> <property name="ignoreName" value="true"/> </module>

abstract class AbstractFirstClass {} // OK abstract class SecondClass {} // OK, name validation is ignored class AbstractThirdClass {} // violation, must be declared as 'abstract' class FourthClass {} // OK, no "abstract" modifier
subsection.p: To configure the check with format:
subsection.source: <module name="AbstractClassName"> <property name="format" value="^Generator.+$"/> </module>

abstract class GeneratorFirstClass {} // OK abstract class SecondClass {} // violation, must match pattern '^Generator.+$' class GeneratorThirdClass {} // violation, must be declared 'abstract' class FourthClass {} // OK, no "abstract" modifier

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that catch parameter names conform to a specified pattern.
Default pattern has the following characteristic:

ul.li: allows names beginning with two lowercase letters followed by at least one uppercase or lowercase letter
allows e abbreviation (suitable for exceptions end errors)
prohibits numbered abbreviations like e1 or t2
prohibits one letter prefixes like pException
prohibits two letter abbreviations like ie or ee
prohibits any other characters than letters

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="CatchParameterName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by any letters or digits is:
subsection.source: <module name="CatchParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][a-zA-Z0-9]+$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that class type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="ClassTypeParameterName"/>
class MyClass1<T> {} // OK class MyClass2<t> {} // violation class MyClass3<abc> {} // violation class MyClass4<LISTENER> {} // violation class MyClass5<RequestT> {} // violation
subsection.p: To configure the check for names that are uppercase word:
subsection.source: <module name="ClassTypeParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[A-Z]{2,}$"/> </module>
class MyClass1<T> {} // violation class MyClass2<t> {} // violation class MyClass3<abc> {} // violation class MyClass4<LISTENER> {} // OK class MyClass5<RequestT> {} // violation
subsection.p: To configure the check for names that are camel case word with T as suffix (Google Style):
subsection.source: <module name="ClassTypeParameterName"> <property name="format" value="(^[A-Z][0-9]?)$|([A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*[T]$)"/> </module>
class MyClass1<T> {} // violation class MyClass2<t> {} // violation class MyClass3<abc> {} // violation class MyClass4<LISTENER> {} // violation class MyClass5<RequestT> {} // OK

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that constant names conform to a specified pattern. A constant is a static and final field or an interface/annotation field, except serialVersionUID and serialPersistentFields.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="ConstantName"/>

class MyClass { public final static int FIRST_CONSTANT1 = 10; // OK protected final static int SECOND_CONSTANT2 = 100; // OK final static int third_Constant3 = 1000; // violation, name 'third_Constant3' must // match pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' private final static int fourth_Const4 = 50; // violation, name 'fourth_Const4' must match // pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' }
subsection.p: The following configuration apart from names allowed by default allows log or logger:
subsection.source: <module name="ConstantName"> <property name="format" value="^log(ger)?$|^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$"/> </module>
subsection.p: The following configuration skip validation on public constant field and protected constant field.
subsection.source: <module name="ConstantName"> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> </module>

class MyClass { public final static int firstConstant = 10; // OK protected final static int secondConstant = 100; // OK final static int thirdConstant = 1000; // violation, name 'thirdConstant' must // match pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' private final static int fourthConstant = 50; // violation, name 'fourthConstant' must match // pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' }

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Checks identifiers with a pattern for a set of illegal names, such as those that are restricted or contextual keywords. Examples include "yield", "record", "_", and "var". Please read more at
Java Language Specification to get to know more about restricted keywords. Since this check uses a pattern to specify valid identifiers, users can also prohibit the usage of certain symbols, such as "$", or any non-ascii character.

tr.td:
subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF
,
INTERFACE_DEF
,
ENUM_DEF
,
ANNOTATION_DEF
,
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF
,
PARAMETER_DEF
,
VARIABLE_DEF
,
METHOD_DEF
,
ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF
,
PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF
,
RECORD_DEF
,
RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF
,
LAMBDA
.

CLASS_DEF
,
INTERFACE_DEF
,
ENUM_DEF
,
ANNOTATION_DEF
,
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF
,
PARAMETER_DEF
,
VARIABLE_DEF
,
METHOD_DEF
,
ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF
,
PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF
,
RECORD_DEF
,
RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF
,
LAMBDA
.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalIdentifierName"/>
subsection.p: To configure the check to include "open" and "transitive" in the set of illegal identifiers:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalIdentifierName"> <property name="format" value="(?i)^(?!(record|yield|var |permits|sealed|open|transitive|_)$).+$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that interface type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="InterfaceTypeParameterName"/>
interface FirstInterface<T> {} // OK interface SecondInterface<t> {} // violation, name 't' must match pattern '^[A-Z]$'
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:
subsection.source: <module name="InterfaceTypeParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z]$"/> </module>
interface FirstInterface<T> {} // OK interface SecondInterface<t> {} // OK interface ThirdInterface<type> {} // violation, name 'type' must // match pattern '^[a-zA-Z]$'

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="LambdaParameterName"/>
Function<String, String> function1 = s -> s.toLowerCase(); // OK Function<String, String> function2 = S -> S.toLowerCase(); // violation, name 'S' // must match pattern '^[a-z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$'
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters is:
subsection.source: <module name="LambdaParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z]([a-zA-Z]+)*$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that local final variable names conform to a specified pattern. A catch parameter and resources in try statements are considered to be a local, final variables.

tr.td:
subset of tokens
VARIABLE_DEF , PARAMETER_DEF , RESOURCE .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="LocalFinalVariableName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only upper case letters and digits is:
subsection.source: <module name="LocalFinalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*$"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names of local final parameters and resources in try statements (without checks on variables):
subsection.source: <module name="LocalFinalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="tokens" value="PARAMETER_DEF,RESOURCE"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that local, non-final variable names conform to a specified pattern. A catch parameter is considered to be a local variable.

tr.td:
Allow one character variable name in
initialization expressions in FOR loop if one char variable name is prohibited by {@code format} regexp.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="LocalVariableName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores is:
subsection.source: <module name="LocalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of one character variable name in initialization expression(like "i") in FOR loop:

An example of how to configure the check to allow one character variable name in
initialization expressions in FOR loop, where regexp allows 2 or more chars:
subsection.source: <module name="LocalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][_a-zA-Z0-9]+$"/> <property name="allowOneCharVarInForLoop" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to that all variables have 3 or more chars in name:
subsection.source: <module name="LocalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][_a-zA-Z0-9]{2,}$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that instance variable names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="MemberName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with "m", followed by an upper case letter, and then letters and digits. Also, suppress the check from being applied to protected and package-private member:
subsection.source: <module name="MemberName"> <property name="format" value="^m[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPackage" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to suppress the check which is applied to public and private member:
subsection.source: <module name="MemberName"> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method names conform to a specified pattern.

Also, checks if a method name has the same name as the residing class. The default is false (it is not allowed). It is legal in Java to have method with the same name as a class. As long as a return type is specified it is a method and not a constructor which it could be easily confused as. Does not check-style the name of an overridden methods because the developer does not have a choice in renaming such methods.

tr.td:
Controls whether to allow a method name to have the same name as the residing class name. This is not to be confused with a constructor. An easy mistake is to place a return type on a constructor declaration which turns it into a method. For example:
class MyClass { public void MyClass() {} //this is a method public MyClass() {} //this is a constructor }
Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="MethodName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores is:
subsection.source: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to allow method names to be equal to the residing class name is:
subsection.source: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="allowClassName" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to disallow method names to be equal to the residing class name is:
subsection.source: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="allowClassName" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to suppress the check to public and protected methods:
subsection.source: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="MethodTypeParameterName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:
subsection.source: <module name="MethodTypeParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z]$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that package names conform to a specified pattern.

The default value of format for module PackageName has been chosen to match the requirements in the Java Language specification and the Sun coding conventions. However, both underscores and uppercase letters are rather uncommon, so most configurations should probably assign value ^[a-z]+(\.[a-z][a-z0-9]*)*$ to format for module PackageName.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="PackageName"/>

package com; // OK package COM; // violation, name 'COM' must match pattern '^[a-z]+(\.[a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*)*$' package com.checkstyle.checks; // OK package com.A.checkstyle.checks; // OK package com.checkstyle1.checks; // OK package com.checkSTYLE.checks; // OK package com._checkstyle.checks_; // OK
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to ensure with packages start with a lowercase letter and only contains lowercase letters or numbers is:
subsection.source: <module name="PackageName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z]+(\.[a-z][a-z0-9]*)*$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method parameter names conform to a specified pattern. By using accessModifiers property it is possible to specify different formats for methods at different visibility levels.
To validate catch parameters please use CatchParameterName.
To validate lambda parameters please use LambdaParameterName.

tr.td: Allows to skip methods with Override annotation from validation.
Access modifiers of methods where parameters are checked.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][_a-zA-Z0-9]+$"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to skip methods with Override annotation from validation:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="ignoreOverridden" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters and digits is:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][a-zA-Z0-9]+$"/> </module>
subsection.p: The following configuration checks that the parameters always start with two lowercase characters and, in addition, that public method parameters cannot be one character long:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z]([a-z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9]*)?$"/> <property name="accessModifiers" value="protected, package, private"/> <message key="name.invalidPattern" value="Parameter name ''{0}'' must match pattern ''{1}''"/> </module> <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][a-z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="accessModifiers" value="public"/> <message key="name.invalidPattern" value="Parameter name ''{0}'' must match pattern ''{1}''"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that pattern variable names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="PatternVariableName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that have a lower case letter, followed by letters and digits, optionally separated by underscore:
subsection.source: <module name="PatternVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to that all variables have 3 or more chars in name:
subsection.source: <module name="PatternVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][_a-zA-Z0-9]{2,}$"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that record component names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="RecordComponentName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only letters in lowercase:
subsection.source: <module name="RecordComponentName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z]+$"/> </module>

record MyRecord1(String value, int other) {} // OK record MyRecord2(String... strings) {} // OK record MyRecord3(double myNumber) {} // violation, the record component name // should match the regular expression "^[a-z]+$"

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that record type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="RecordTypeParameterName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:
subsection.source: <module name="RecordTypeParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z]$"/> </module>
record MyRecord1<T> {} // OK record MyRecord2<t> {} // OK record MyRecord3<abc> {} // violation, the record type parameter // name should match the regular expression "^[a-zA-Z]$"

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that static, non-final variable names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="StaticVariableName"/>
subsection.p: An example of how to suppress the check to public and protected types is:
subsection.source: <module name="StaticVariableName"> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores. Also, suppress the check from being applied to private and package-private types:
subsection.source: <module name="StaticVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPackage" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that type names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , RECORD_DEF .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="TypeName"/>

public interface FirstName {} // OK protected class SecondName {} // OK enum Third_Name {} // violation, name 'Third_Name' must match pattern '^[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$' private class FourthName_ {} // violation, name 'FourthName_' // must match pattern '^[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$'
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores. Also, suppress the check from being applied to protected and private type:
subsection.source: <module name="TypeName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> </module>

public interface firstName {} // OK public class SecondName {} // violation, name 'SecondName' // must match pattern '^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$' protected class ThirdName {} // OK private class FourthName {} // OK
subsection.p: The following configuration element ensures that interface names begin with "I_", followed by letters and digits:
subsection.source: <module name="TypeName"> <property name="format" value="^I_[a-zA-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="tokens" value="INTERFACE_DEF"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.
